Let’s get some practice¶

Reading a tutorial is fun, but what about running some experiments without guidance.

As an exercise, you should try to obtain a performance plot for different repetition codes with different lengths.

The repetition code of length \(2t + 1\) for any natural number \(t\) is the linear code with codewords \(000\ldots 0\) and \(111\ldots 1\). It is a code of dimension \(k = 1\) where each codeword is \((2t + 1\) repetitions of the \(0\) or \(1\) bit. The parity check matrix of this code is the \(2t \times 2t + 1\) matrix

(3)¶\[\begin{align} H = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 & \ldots & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 0 & \ldots & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & \ldots & 0 & 0 \\ & \vdots & & \vdots & & \vdots & \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \ldots & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}\]

A simple decoder for is the majority vote decoder. Simply, if the Hamming weight of a message is greater than \( t \), returns the \( 111 \ldots 1 \) codeword, else returns the \( 000 \ldots 0 \).

Warning

Don’t go to the next page to fast, it has the solution to this exercise.
